text:
USA TODAY Sports bracketology: No. 3 seeds Duke, UCLA are title contenders It was a grand night for two of college basketball's blue bloods on Thursday night. Post to Facebook USA TODAY Sports bracketology: No. 3 seeds Duke, UCLA are title contenders It was a grand night for two of college basketball's blue bloods on Thursday night.  //usat.ly/2kWYMIw   Join the Nation's Conversation   USA TODAY Sports bracketology: No. 3 seeds Duke, UCLA are title contenders Shelby Mast, Special for USA TODAY Sports Published 10:37   | Updated 60 minutes ago CLOSE Share Gonzaga will spend another week atop the USA TODAY Sports coaches poll. USA TODAY Sports UCLA Bruins forward TJ Leaf (22) dunks the ball against the Oregon Ducks during the second half at Pauley Pavilion. The UCLA Bruins won 82-79. (Photo: Kelvin Kuo, USA TODAY Sports) 2 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Two of college basketball's biggest blue bloods picked up big time, momentous wins on Thursday night. And both are sizzling No. 3 seeds in the latest bracket. 
Duke had been at the No. 3 line before shooting past archrival North Carolina , but now are even safer following that win. The more times passes, the further the Blue Devils' January rough goes in the rear-view mirror and the more they look like title contenders. UCLA needed a huge comeback to top Oregon , and the Bruins did it. They needed that win to stay in the Pac-12 race, but they also needed another signature victory to stay a protected seed. And they looked every bit the part of a team that has earned that distinction. 
Wisconsin squeaked by Nebraska and have bumped up a line. Purdue knocked Indiana from the bracket and they too move up. To the Cincinnati and West Virginia fans, your teams dropped only because of those that moved up. 
► No. 1 seeds: Villanova, Gonzaga, Kansas, Baylor 
► Last four in: Kansas State, Marquette, Rhode Island, Michigan 
► First four out: Indiana, Clemson, Wake Forest, Vanderbilt 
Moving In : UNC-Ashville, Michigan, New Orleans 
Moving out : Winthrop, Indiana, Sam Houston 
► Others considered for at-large bids (in no particular order): Miami, Georgetown, Arkansas, Illinois, Wichita State, Ole Miss, Auburn, Alabama, Texas Tech, Georgia, Providence, Houston, Memphis, Ohio State, Utah. 
► On life support: Penn State, Pittsburgh, Stanford, Texas A&M, Iowa, North Carolina State. 
► No longer considered: UConn, Texas, UTA, Charleston, New Mexico, Boise State, LaSalle, Davidson, Chattanooga, Saint Bonaventure, Saint Joseph's, BYU, Oklahoma,​ Charleston, Nebraska, Temple. 
► Multi-bid conferences: ACC (9), Big Ten (7), Big 12 (7), Big East (6), Pac-12 (5), SEC (4), A-10 (3), AAC (2), WCC (2). 
MORE COLLEGE HOOPS NEWS No. 1 Gonzaga remains lone unbeaten with LMU rout Conference Leaders 
► Or highest RPI from projected one-bid conferences - (23 total): Vermont (America East), Florida Gulf Coast (Atlantic Sun), Weber State (Big Sky), UNC-Asheville (Big South), UC Davis (Big West), UNC-Wilmington (CAA), Middle Tennessee State (Conference USA), Valparaiso (Horizon), Yale (Ivy League), Monmouth (MAAC), Akron (MAC), N.C. Central (MEAC), Illinois State (Missouri Valley), Nevada (Mountain West), Mount Saint Mary's (Northeast), Belmont (Ohio Valley), Bucknell (Patriot), Furman (Southern), New Orleans (Southland), Texas Southern (SWAC), North Dakota State (Summit), Arkansas State (Sun Belt), New Mexico State (WAC). 
Banned from participating: Hawaii, Southern Mississippi, Alcorn State, Savannah State, Northern Colorado Transition Schools, ineligible for the tourney: Abilene Christian (Southland), Grand Canyon (WAC), Incarnate Word (Southland), Massachusetts-Lowell (American East) 
*** 
Note: All RPI and statistical data is used from WarrenNolan.com . 
About our bracketologist: Shelby Mast has been projecting the field since 2005 and has finished as one of the top 5 national bracketologists for his website, Bracket W.A.G. He’s predicted for The Indianapolis Star, collegeinsider.com and is an inaugural member of the Super 10 Selection Committee. Follow him on Twitter @BracketWag .

Johnson (4) defend during the first half at Fred Bramlage Coliseum.
